factoid: Balashëv entered a small reception room.
One door of the reception room led into a study.
The study was the one from which the Russian Emperor had dispatched Balashëv on his mission.
Balashëv stood in the room for a minute or two, waiting.
He heard hurried footsteps beyond the door.
Both halves of the door were opened rapidly.
The room was silent after the door opened.
From the study, footsteps were heard, firm and resolute.
The footsteps were those of Napoleon.
Napoleon had just finished dressing for his ride.
Napoleon wore a blue uniform.
Napoleon's blue uniform had a white waistcoat that covered his rotund stomach.
Napoleon wore white leather breeches that were tightly fitting the fat thighs of his short legs.
Napoleon wore Hessian boots.
Napoleon had short hair that had been brushed.
One lock of Napoleon's hair hung down in the middle of his broad forehead.
Napoleon's plump white neck stood out sharply above the black collar of his uniform.
Napoleon smelled of Eau de Cologne.
Napoleon had a full face that looked rather young.
Napoleon's face had a prominent chin.
Napoleon wore a gracious and majestic expression of imperial welcome.
Napoleon entered the room briskly, jerking at every step, with his head slightly thrown back.
Napoleon had a short corpulent figure with broad thick shoulders, a chest and stomach protruding.
Napoleon had an imposing and stately appearance.
Napoleon was in the best of spirits that day.
Napoleon nodded in answer to Balashëv's low and respectful bow.
Napoleon began speaking like a man who values every moment of his time.
Napoleon said, "Good day, General!"
Napoleon said, "I have received the letter you brought from the Emperor Alexander and am very glad to see you."
Napoleon glanced with his large eyes into Balashëv's face and immediately looked past him.
Napoleon was not interested in Balashëv's personality.
Napoleon was only interested in what took place within his own mind.
Napoleon believed that everything in the world depended entirely on his will.
Napoleon said, "I do not desire war, but it has been forced on me."
Napoleon said, "I am ready to receive any explanations you can give me."
Napoleon explained his reasons for dissatisfaction with the Russian government.
Napoleon spoke in a calmly moderate and amicable tone.
Balashëv was firmly persuaded that Napoleon wished for peace and intended to enter into negotiations.
After Napoleon finished speaking, he looked inquiringly at the Russian envoy Balashëv.
Balashëv began a speech he had prepared long before.
Balashëv said, "Sire! The Emperor, my master..."
Napoleon's eyes bent on Balashëv, causing confusion.
Napoleon said, "You are flurried—compose yourself!"
Napoleon smiled scarcely perceptibly.
Napoleon looked at Balashëv's uniform and sword.
Balashëv recovered and began to speak.
Balashëv said that Emperor Alexander did not consider Kurákin's demand for passports a sufficient cause for war.
Balashëv said that Kurákin acted on his own initiative and without Emperor Alexander's assent.
Balashëv said that Emperor Alexander did not desire war.
Balashëv said that Emperor Alexander had no relations with England.
Napoleon interposed, "Not yet!"
Napoleon frowned and nodded slightly as a sign that Balashëv might proceed.
Balashëv added that Emperor Alexander wished for peace, but would not enter into negotiations except on condition that...
Balashëv remembered the words Emperor Alexander had inserted in the rescript to Saltykóv: "So long as a single armed foe remains on Russian soil."
Balashëv could not utter those words, though he wished to do so.
Balashëv said, "On condition that the French army retires beyond the Niemen."
Napoleon noticed Balashëv's embarrassment when uttering these last words.
Napoleon's face twitched.
Napoleon's left leg calf began to quiver rhythmically.
Napoleon began speaking in a louder tone and more hurriedly than before.
During the speech that followed, Balashëv lowered his eyes more than once.
Balashëv involuntarily noticed the quivering of Napoleon's left leg.
The quivering increased as Napoleon raised his voice.
